clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Intravenous Vitamin C on SOFA Score Among Septic Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Intravenous Vitamin C on Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) Score Among Septic Patients: Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study aimed to explore the effect of intravenous (IV) vitamin C on sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) score among septic patients in intensive care unit (ICU).

detailed_description.textblock: "This study was approved by the Ethics and Research Committee of Universitas Indonesia. This study was a randomized clinical trial held from April to July 2019 in Cipto Mangunkusumo Hospital. 33 patients that met the inclusion criteria were included in the study. Subjects were divided into two groups: group A (intervention group, n = 18) received parenteral infusions of 1,5 g/6 hours of vitamin C and 200 mg thiamine, while group B (control group, n = 15) received 200 mg thiamine only. baseline demographic data was recorded on the first day. SOFA score was recorded at baseline, 24 hours, 48 hours, and 72 hours after treatment. Data were analyzed using SPSS (Statistical Package for Social Sciences) software."

primary_outcome.description: Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score score measured at several specified times. higher score indicates higher mortality in septic patients.

arm_group.description: patients who received intravenous vitamin C and thiamine

intervention.description: vitamin C 1,5 g/6 hours IV + thiamine 200 mg/12 hours for 3 days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients with sepsis diagnosis based on sepsis-3 criteria in the ICU in between 6 hours to 24 hours post resuscitation after sepsis diagnosis
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients with chronic kidney problems on haemodialysis,
- patients with kidney stones or kidney problem within the last 3 months
